um and so in practice we think about kind of going roughly from left to right but there's

pause on thinking about the science of data science how do we actually
do data science um and in statistics and machine learning and ai and data science
broadly and in every scientific field um so any kind of study that's being done we
have a huge emphasis on having reproducible or replicable results these these ideas are going to be made
far more complicated by the pipeline nature of these problems so for example there are a few different
definitions of reproducibility and reputability and i'm just showing you the ones that i'm using
reproducibility here i'm thinking about the ability to implement the same experiment the exact same code
the exact same procedures with the same data and i get the exact same results so if you take my code and you run it
you get the same coefficient that i reported you see everything is exactly the same
replicability i'm using a national academy's definition here obtaining consistent results across
studies aimed at answering the same scientific question each of which has obtained its own data
set in similar ways so for example that might be that i run a study trying to
think about an intervention on improving educational outcomes and someone in another university
runs a similarly designed study to try to also measure the same education
intervention but they get their own sample they have their own surveyors
etc and if we both get that the intervention was successful then we're saying that the finding was
applicable and almost everybody can agree on the need to carefully document all code
all analyses algorithms etc and a subset of that group would add requirements to publicly post and disseminate all of
that but of course there are sometimes proprietary issues sensitivity issues confidentiality
um so that doesn't always isn't always feasible in practice so so what does that actually mean
though reproducible and replicable for students and practitioners let's talk about what happens when people actually do this
so the first is reproducibility so reproducibility i'm thinking about okay i did the exact same steps i did last
time and i get the same thing so that's good what we really see in practice quite a
bit is something like oh god i can't find my notes i'm looking at my work from six months ago i have no
idea how i got this result why doesn't it look the same what is happening
am i gonna get in trouble and as a professor i can tell you that we actually have had
students who copy their friends code and run it but then tell us oh no we
were just thinking about reproducibility we weren't really cheating so that's that's kind of a funny aside
um and from replicability this one's a little bit trickier for for industry and academia um
this could be that my friends or my classmates or my colleagues and i have different random samples of the same
study or the same data set the same distribution um and they get slightly different but similar results
that's something we see a lot in the classroom that they're very confused about um well if i get or or sometimes one
group will get a significant result and the other group will get an insignificant result and they have a hard time reconciling that that's just
due to the slight to the different randomness that they're getting in their in their projects something we see a lot in industry and
in large research groups is that when you're trying to compare research you're trying to see if it's replicable or a new product that you're
getting ready to launch or get a new process you're getting ready to adopt you know colleagues can collect
different data sets in a similar way but they get different results possibly on the same question
so what we're saying there is um you might have done an analysis to see if you're ready to launch a new
product and then your colleagues do a similar analysis and they say we're not ready to launch the same
product well how is that replicable is that okay should we move forward um and another
big uh issue that faces a lot of industry people when we're thinking about data science
and replicability is that they don't have the time or the money or the bandwidth to reproduce things or
to see if things are replicable so you can't just keep running their analyses over and over and over again
at some point you have to make a decision and move forward this is incredibly challenging for most industry partners working on data science
problems the other thing that's been taking a hit is this concept of p values
so do we if something's significant do we keep it if it's not significant do we throw it
away and it's totally useless uh there's kind of a big move to de-emphasize p-values
and i'll just mention here that um coming out of the american statistical association there's kind of this comment
i'm sort of paraphrasing it here but to think about p values is more just like swiping right on tinder
and it's not really that you're lifelong committing to that particular result but more than just you find it
interesting and you'd like to learn more about that right there so that's kind of where p values are are
heading for statistics so so what's the big kicker here for the
science of data science we can do all of these technical things and we have all these amazing software packages and tools
and uh really smart developers working on fantastic products and much of data science relies on
extracting signal and structure using these fancy machine learning algorithms but quite a bit of is based on human
subjective decisions this is the part that everyone is really struggling with but it's
it's kind of the most important part and hopefully that's one of the big takeaways from this morning here's a really small
example this is a very common data set that's used pedagogically and also in astro
statistics this is a one variable on velocities of 82 galaxies
and the reason that people use this is it represents the difficulties in trying to see how many different

and the difference here the point that we're trying to make is in the upper left i have a histogram with a certain number
of bins in the upper right that histogram has fewer bins down to the lower left i have more bins
and in the lower right i have a box plot so if you were just looking at this
graph and you were trying to determine how many groups you have or how many bumps you would get very different
answers depending on which graph you looked at most algorithms to determine whether or
not there's multimodality are based on some kind of estimate of the density or in which a histogram is
like an example of a piecewise constant density estimate so this upper left one you might say there are three groups the upper right
you might say there's one the lower left you might say there are four and the box plots you can't tell a

depending on just how many bins you chose a person shows that a person shows how many bins maybe they used a rule of

we can see this more common a little bit more effectively maybe in this uh famous
many analyst one data set study that just came out recently and in this study they gave uh 29

science and they were given the same data set and they had the same question the question is simply are soccer
referees more likely to give red cards to players with dark skin than to players with light skin and
that's that's their terminology in this analysis the teams worked independently but at some point they
exchanged the current or their current work and got some peer review and ideas and then they revised their work and
submitted the final conclusions so reasonably trained people smart
people with data same data set same question and these are the kinds of results that they got
back so just um every single one of these rectangles these boxes is associated
with a team the circle is the point estimate so it's the um how likely how much more likely for
example are referees to give red cards to dark skinned players in the world cup if it's green then it became it was
significant in the in the analysis excuse me the analyst models and the width of the box is associated
with the cut list is just associated with confidence loosely so if you got to see all 29 of these
research of these research teams you probably would say yes i think there's a significant effect
here most of these teams are getting results roughly in the same range they're significant
i feel okay about you know saying that yes there is a statistically significant
effect for referees being more likely to give red cards to dark skin players but what if you came over here and you
happened to be the team that was this first box so the first box i have it's not
significant and it actually says the referees are less likely but not significant if i came over to
the far right i would see that i have an effect that's significant my green circle and it's
almost three times as likely but that confidence is huge so
the point that we're trying to make here thinking about the science of data science is very often you only get to see one of
these boxes your team does an analysis to make a decision and you get one of them you don't get the chance to
see 30 different takes on this problem but if you got one of the ones that was insignificant you'd think okay there's
no effect if you got one that is significant you think okay there is it's extremely difficult to think about
what is the true answer when so much of the work depends on human decisions
and again these were all reasonable analyses that were well vetted and checked like the the
work here is not wrong they just made slightly different decisions about how they approach the problem and that's really the tricky thing that
we're working on so if we come back to the science of data science workflow picture i had
we can think of it as this left to right workflow where i'm going to ask my questions i'm going to design my studies
i'm going to go find those data warehouses and try to turn them into something that approximates a data lake
maybe it's a data swamp or a collection of data ponds or puddles but i'm doing all of this work and i'm
moving through this workflow from left to right but the reality is much more of this so
if you are familiar this choose your own adventure books were um popular maybe i don't know 25 30 years
ago um but if you have if you're not familiar with these books these are stories that you start to read
and you read a few pages and at the end of the page it tells you uh so you're in a cave do you want to go
into the cave go to page 12 do you want to leave and go into the forest go to page 16.
and as you move through it you kind of determine your own path well anybody who's ever read choose your own
adventure books and i'll out myself right here knows that a lot of those paths end in death
so it's like i went to page 12 i entered the cave and then my lantern broke and the rocks
caved in and then i died and what we usually do then if you're reading the book is you go back to the
page you were just on and you take another path that's very very common or akin to what
happens with data science people try things it doesn't work they go
back they try something else they go talk to other people they think about
how they might redo their visualizations they go back and look for other data sets so when i think about how to model
or analyze this left to right workflow the reality is i'm kind of modeling this
crazy tree structure this looped iterative tree structure where people are making decisions about
what they're doing um different people are doing different paths hopefully they're all converging on
reasonable results but without understanding the decisions that everybody made we're not really going to be able to
understand the results that we have at the end of the day
so where does that leave us so we've been moving in data science towards thinking a lot
about this idea of behavioral data science so uh in the first wave of these data
science educational programs there was this explosion everybody was going to be a data scientist there were like 500 masters
programs and it really kind of uh turned into like the people's science and
and what i mean by the people's science is um we don't really well i hope we don't
have like six million people dissecting frogs in their backyard but we do have millions of people
looking at data they look at data when they are trying to figure out what articles to
read on their news feed they're looking at data when they're trying to decide if they should take an umbrella to work
people are constantly making decisions with data so my seven-year-old she when she was
first visiting her new kindergarten they did uh they did an activity with them where they made
bar charts out of gummy bears so this kid is five years old you know sorting and categorizing and
then stacking her gummy bears deciding which ones she had the most color of and then you know she got to
eat it all it was like the best data science ever but everybody is consuming data the
tricky thing from our perspective from a scientist perspective from a academic perspective from a software
developer perspective you know building these tools for people we don't have a clue what people are actually
doing or why they're doing it more importantly so how can we incorporate this human
decision making into a data science interface or a pipeline and so we've been thinking a lot about
behavioral data science so some things you might do to think about this are
doing think alouds you can record what you're thinking while you're doing your work this is completely terrifying to listen
to what you were thinking while you were doing your work we do these experiments quite often with
students and you can really capture a lot of misconceptions and problems if you can get people to practice thinking out loud
you can do crowdsourcing where you have groups work independently on the same problem this can be very powerful but it also is
very hard because it comes with time bandwidth money to be able to
reproduce the same problem excuse me as an analysis over and over again is actually is actually quite
